abstract: The success of young entrepreneurs is rooted in the commercial, competitive, nonegalitarian and open nature of American society.
snippet: The success of young entrepreneurs is rooted in the commercial, competitive, nonegalitarian and open nature of American society.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Dell (of Dell Inc.) sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard University sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

headline.main: The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
headline.print_headline: The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
